matched.actualTitle: JWT "none" Algorithm Enabled - Complete Authentication Bypass / JWT Signature Bypass Leading to Privilege Escalation
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same core vulnerability: JWT tokens with 'none' algorithm are accepted without signature verification. The expected finding focuses on privilege escalation from user to admin role, while the actual findings document the complete authentication bypass and the specific POC demonstrating role modification from 'user' to 'admin'. The actual findings provide more detailed technical evidence and impact assessment of the same vulnerability.

extra.title: Missing Rate Limiting on Login Endpoint - Credential Stuffing Vulnerability
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate vulnerability not in the expected findings. The login endpoint accepts unlimited rapid login attempts (7,500+ per minute) without rate limiting, throttling, or account lockout mechanisms, enabling credential stuffing and brute force attacks.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Login Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - The login endpoint lacks CSRF token validation, Origin/Referer header validation, and SameSite cookie attributes. This is a legitimate security gap not covered in the expected findings.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Token in Login Form
extra.assessment: New discovery - The login form HTML contains no CSRF token field and the POST handler does not validate CSRF tokens. While related to the CSRF Protection finding, this provides specific technical evidence of the missing control.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers on Login Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application is missing critical HTTP security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, Strict-Transport-Security, Content-Security-Policy, X-XSS-Protection). This is a legitimate security gap in defense-in-depth.

extra.title: Weak Credential Policy - Default Test Credentials Accepted
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application accepts extremely weak credentials (user:user) with no minimum password complexity requirements and no account lockout mechanisms. This is a legitimate vulnerability enabling easy unauthorized access through dictionary/brute force attacks.

extra.title: Missing Critical Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - Comprehensive assessment of missing security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Strict-Transport-Security, Content-Security-Policy, Access-Control-Allow-Origin, HttpOnly flags). This represents defense-in-depth security gaps.

extra.title: Missing Security Cookie Flags - HttpOnly and Secure Flags Not Set
extra.assessment: New discovery - Authentication tokens are stored in cookies without HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags. This enables XSS-based token theft, MITM interception, and CSRF attacks. A significant vulnerability not covered in expected findings.

extra.title: No Token Expiration - JWT Tokens Valid Indefinitely
extra.assessment: New discovery - JWT tokens lack expiration claims (exp, iat, nbf, jti), making them valid indefinitely. This allows stolen tokens to provide permanent access without time-based invalidation. A critical finding not in expected vulnerabilities.

extra.title: Hardcoded Credentials in Source Code
extra.assessment: New discovery - User credentials (user:user, admin:AdmAQ#DCFQ) and SECRET_KEY ('supersecretkey') are hardcoded in source code without encryption or secure storage. Credentials are not loaded from environment variables or secrets management systems. This is a legitimate security misconfiguration.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Allowed HTTP Methods Exposed
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application exposes allowed HTTP methods through Allow headers in responses and OPTIONS requests. While a low-severity information disclosure issue, it aids attacker reconnaissance by eliminating trial-and-error enumeration of supported methods.
